message.content:
Popular board games from the 1970s include:

1. Mastermind - a game of logic and deduction where one player creates a secret color code, and the other player tries to guess it within a certain number of guesses.
2. Othello/Reversi - an abstract strategy game with simple rules but deep strategy, played between two players on an 8x8 board with black and white pieces called "discs."
3. Uno - a classic card game that involves matching colors or numbers, racing to get rid of all your cards, and using special action cards to keep things interesting.
4. Payday - a family-friendly money management board game in which players move through the days of their month trying to make ends meet while dealing with unexpected expenses.
5. Backgammon – An ancient strategy board game that has since become popular worldwide involving making moves based on dice rolls while attempting to remove all your checkers before your opponent.
6. Dungeons & Dragons - Though not technically classified as only a 'board' game; it's probably the most iconic tabletop role-playing game first released in 1974 by Gary Gygax and Dave Arneson where players create fantastic characters for storytelling gameplay exploring dungeons slaying monsters., etc
7. Connect Four – A play-based tactics vertical checkerboarding match requiring winning four pieces aligned horizontally vertically or diagonally.

As you mentioned Scrabble earlier we hence assume everyone knows about Scramble so didn't add it here :)
